etymologies: early 16th century (in the sense ‘masquerade or masked ball’): probably a back-formation (influenced by French masque‘mask’) from masker, from Italian mascar ‘person wearing a mask’

definitions: a form of amateur dramatic entertainment, popular among the nobility in 16th- and 17th-century England, which consisted of dancing and acting performed by masked players.
shortDefinitions: form of amateur dramatic entertainment, popular among nobility in 16th- and 17th-century England

crossReferenceMarkers: variant spelling of mask (sense 3 of the noun)

examples.text: adding a treatment masque to your cleansing routine works wonders
